docs.lead_paragraph: Recent studies suggest that the current policy of emphasizing abstinence in sex education and minimizing contraceptive use should be turned around.

docs.lead_paragraph: The vote sets the stage for court battles and social clashes between Mexico’s religious conservatives and liberals.

headline.main: Mexico City Legalizes Abortion Early in Term
headline.print_headline: Mexico City Legalizes Abortion Early in Term

docs.lead_paragraph: Ethiopian Rebels Hit Oil Site Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia, killing more than 70 people, including nine Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopia's worst rebel attacks in years. After a fierce hourlong battle, the attackers rushed away, taking at least six Chinese hostages with them. PAGE A6 A Push for Education The billionaires Bill Gates and Eli Broad will spend $60 million to try to vault education high on the agenda of the 2008 presidential race. They plan to run advertisements calling for more consistent curriculum standards, a longer school day and merit pay for teachers. PAGE A21 Acquittal in Indonesia An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining, an American company, and one of its senior executives of charges of polluting a bay with toxic waste, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia. PAGE A8 About New York In his first About New York column, Jim Dwyer details the plight of a father and son who were detained as protesters during the Republican National Convention. PAGE B1 New Planet May Be Earthlike Astronomers have discovered a planet 20 light-years from Earth and within the so-called habitable zone from its star. PAGE A16 A New Leader in Auto Sales In Detroit, the news that Toyota had, at least for the most recent quarter, unseated General Motors as the world's top-selling automobile company was greeted with some anguish, some anger and a sense of resignation. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Mexico City Allows Abortion Mexico City approved a bill to permit abortion in the first three months of pregnancy, setting the stage for battles in court and between conservatives and liberals. PAGE A8

docs.lead_paragraph: A popular old wives’ tale holds that for every baby a woman has, she is bound to lose a tooth. Is it true?

docs.lead_paragraph: The study tracked women prospectively to see if those who reported having abortions were more likely to develop breast cancer in the future and found that they were not.

headline.main: Breast Cancer Not Linked to Abortion, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Breast Cancer Not Linked To Abortion, Study Says

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM Gain a child, lose a tooth. THE FACTS A popular old wives' tale holds that for every baby a woman has, she is bound to lose a tooth, supposedly because the pregnancy interferes with calcium absorption and increases hormones that affect oral health.
docs.abstract: Research establishes link between dental problems and pregnancy, but specific factors involved are still unknown; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Postures in Public, Facts in the Womb'' (column, April 22): David Brooks writes, ''In the beginning there is the womb and the creature inside.'' Sounds as if ''the womb'' is sitting over there in the corner, minding its own business, unattached to a person!
docs.abstract: Seven letters comment on David Brooks Apr 22 Op-Ed column on abortion debate; Kate Permut argues choice belongs solely to women; Daniel H Pilon does not understand how Brooks reaches recommendation to keep any abortion legal; Agatha Moorad says decisions around issue are torturous and should not be within scope of Supreme Court; Jean A Starks contends Brooks's proposal is too neat and does not allow for extenuating circumstances; Timothy P Wymore argues criteria proposed by Brooks for which life should be protected are too arbitrary; Joyce Lockard wonders why contraception is not part of debate; Dr Richard Zweig, replying to Apr 20 letter on Supreme Court decision, contends medical issues are outside purview of court
